title: Woman discovers bizarre insect camouflaged as a fern tree in her backyard
text:
An 'awestruck' gardener has had a bizarre encounter with a insect so rare she's been forced to take to social media to uncover its identity.

Marte Blaker discovered he insect at her at her home in Billinudgel, near Byron Bay, in a moment she said was 'quiet special', Yahoo News reported.

Once posted Ms Blaker quickly realised she wasn't the only one who was both enchanted but stumped by exactly what kind of insect she'd encountered.

A woman took to social media looking for answers after discovering a bizarre insect camouflaged as a fern tree in her back garden (pictured)

The footage shows the creature, looking almost identical to a leave from fern, moving across the garden bed.

'Nature never ceases to amaze me. Awestruck in wonder of its biodiversity,' one social media user responded.

Another described the creature as 'truly incredible'.

Senior Curator of Entomology at Museums Victoria Dr Ken Walker identified the creature as an 'eucyclodes caterpillar'.

Entomologist and nature photographer Matthew Connors said camouflage was a distinctive feature of the caterpillar.

'The reason for its strange appearance is not so much that it wants to look like a fern but more that it's aiming to look less like a caterpillar,' he said.

'It helps in confusing predators that are looking for prey that looks like a regular caterpillar'.

The caterpillar will eventually evolve into a Lichen moth, which can be found all over the world, except most Australian species are endemic, only occurring in Australia.

The caterpillars typically feed on lichens and algae and the one Ms Blaker found had camouflaged itself to prevent predators from recognising it as prey.
description: An 'awestruck' gardener has had an bizarre encounter with a insect so rare she's been forced to take to social media to uncover its identity.
authors: Adam Mccleery For Daily Mail Australia
